prompt: <description>Part 1: Three-dimensional rectangular prism with a slightly tapered top and bottom, and a series of rectangular cutouts along its length. Start by creating a new coordinate system with the following properties: * Euler Angles: [0.0, 0.0, -90.0] * Translation Vector: [0.0, 0.4102, 0.0] Now, create the 2D sketch on the XY plane: * Sketch a rectangle with the following line segments: 1. [0.0, 0.1368] to [0.2079, 0.1368] 2. [0.2079, 0.1368] to [0.2079, 0.0] 3. [0.2079, 0.0] to [0.75, 0.0] 4. [0.75, 0.0] to [0.75, 0.5527] 5. [0.75, 0.5527] to [0.2079, 0.5527] 6. [0.2079, 0.5527] to [0.2079, 0.3564] 7. [0.2079, 0.3564] to [0.0, 0.3564] 8. [0.0, 0.3564] to [0.0, 0.1368] Next, scale the 2D sketch along the normal direction using a scaling factor of 0.75. Then, transform the 2D sketch into a 3D sketch using the given euler angles and the translation vector. Extrude the 2D sketch along the normal direction by 0.4102 units. The resulting shape will be a three-dimensional rectangular prism with a slightly tapered top and bottom, and a series of rectangular cutouts along its length. Part 2: Cylindrical object with a tapered top and bottom, resembling a metallic tube or pipe. Start by creating a new coordinate system with the following properties: * Euler Angles: [0.0, 0.0, -90.0] * Translation Vector: [0.316, 0.0, 0.2555] Now, create the 2D sketch on the XY plane: * Sketch a circle with its center at [0.1014, 0.1014] and a radius of 0.1014 Next, scale the 2D sketch along the normal direction using a scaling factor of 0.2029. Then, transform the 2D sketch into a 3D sketch using the given euler angles and the translation vector. Extrude the 2D sketch along the opposite normal direction by 0.4102 units. The resulting shape will be a cylindrical object with a tapered top and bottom, resembling a metallic tube or pipe. Note: The final shape is a three-dimensional rectangular prism with a cylindrical hole in the center. You can obtain it by combining the two intermediate parts, "part_1" and "part_2", using the boolean operation "CutFeatureOperation" to remove the cylindrical hole from the rectangular prism.</description>

prompt: <description>**Part 1: A rectangular metal bracket with two holes on the top edge** The first part of the assembly is a rectangular metal bracket with two holes on the top edge. The bracket will be constructed using a single 2D sketch which will then be extruded to create the 3D model. **Sketching the base of the bracket** 1. Begin by creating a new coordinate system at (0, 0.05, 0) with Euler angles (0, 0, -90) and a translation vector (0, 0.05, 0). 2. Create a new sketch on the XY plane of the coordinate system. 3. Draw the outline of the bracket using a series of lines and arcs: - Start by drawing an arc with a radius of 0.0375 centered at (0.1489, 0.6338). - Next, draw a line from the endpoint of the arc to the point (0.75, 0.0). - Draw a line from (0.75, 0.0) to (0.75, 0.275). - Draw an arc with a radius of 0.0375 centered at (0.7427, 0.2927) from (0.75, 0.275) to (0.725, 0.3). - Draw a line from (0.725, 0.3) to (0.325, 0.3). - Draw an arc with a radius of 0.0375 centered at (0.3073, 0.3073) from (0.325, 0.3) to (0.3, 0.325). - Draw a line from (0.3, 0.325) to (0.3, 0.725). - Draw an arc with a radius of 0.0375 centered at (0.2927, 0.2927) from (0.3, 0.725) to (0.275, 0.75). - Draw a line from (0.275, 0.75) to (0.0, 0.75). - Finally, draw a line from (0.0, 0.75) back to the starting point (0.0, 0.075). **Adding the holes** 4. Next, add the two holes on the top edge of the bracket. To do this, draw two circles with a radius of 0.0375 centered at (0.1558, 0.1721) and (0.6288, 0.16) respectively. These circles should be tangent to the outline of the bracket. **Extruding the sketch** 5. With the sketch complete, extrude it by 0.05 units towards the normal (0, 0, 1) and by 0 units in the opposite direction. This will create the final 3D model of the bracket. 6. The resulting part will have a length of 0.75 units, a width of 0.05 units, and a height of 0.75 units, as determined by the sketch scale and extrusion depths. **Adding the bracket to the assembly** 7. This part can now be added to the assembly using a "NewBodyFeatureOperation". This will create a new solid body for the bracket. This body will serve as the base for subsequent parts which can be added using appropriate boolean operations (such as "JoinFeatureOperation", "CutFeatureOperation", or "IntersectFeatureOperation").</description>
